document_data.name: Slatey Marven
document_data.mainbody:
'''Slatey Marven''' was a commoner from the [[Baldur's Gate/Lower City|Lower City]] of [[Baldur's Gate]] in the late 15{{th}} century [[DR]].
{{Quote|If you can't take feedback, how do you ever improve, eh? May as well paint in your bedroom and never show a damn soul.|Slatey Marven}}
document_data.Description: Slatey was a [[human]] woman with a sun-kissed skin tone, big brown eyes, and black hair gathered in tight cornrow braids.
document_data.History: In the {{YearlinkName|1492}}, during the [[Absolute crisis]], the [[half-orcish]] artist named [[Splatters Doolug]] spent his days painting murals on the [[Old Wall (Baldur's Gate)|Old Wall]]. His art faced criticism from some passersby like Slatey Marven, who thought Doolug took criticism poorly. She believed that artists were too soft and that their egos crumbled with a single negative comment, instead of taking the criticism as feedback to grow and improve.
